author: kevaundray
content:
I think the easiest solution with the current architecture for the sequencer, would be for the sequencer to pre-generate X amount of access codes, then in the frontend have some way of sending an access code when you request to sign in.

Once sign in is successful, the sequencer removes the access code from a Set, so it can no longer be used

author: kevaundray
content:
The downside of this is that you have to decide upfront how many people will participate.

A different approach which allows for participants to be added on the go is to:

1. Have the sequencer generate a secret.
2. Whenever someone needs to be added the sequencer hashes their secret plus none : y = hash(secret || nonce) 
3. A contributor sends none and y when they want to authorise
4. Sequencer checks if they have seen ‚Äònonce‚Äô and checks that the preimage is correct

Method like this allow you to generate access codes on the go, though I‚Äôm not 100% sure this is a needed requirement, if we just generate 10K access codes upfront

author: bridge-bot
content: <Marcin> Assuming we do a permit list: rather than doing some custom solution, I'd much rather have the seqeuncer pull a fresh permit-list of user IDs (wallets / gh names) from a Google Spreadsheet. Can be done in ~20 lines of dumb code on the sequencer side, and we get what amounts to an awesome admin panel: anyone you want to have the ability to add people just gets write rights to that spreadsheet. Bonus points: can also integrate with google forms for even more free automation. The whole "how to do a permit list" problem is trivial technically, the pain lies in maintaining the list contents, making sure we don't send the same secret twice etc. This solution makes it all quite easy and mindless ‚Äì fewer ways to screw it all up.
